original: chu dron po de yang gling rnams kyi nang du 'gro ste /
analyzed: chu dron po de yang gling rnams kyi nang du 'gro ste /
translated: The warm water also enters the continents.

original: shing gang dag chu dron po des bde bar skye bar 'gyur ba'i shing de dag ni lo ma yod pa dang / me tog yod pa dang / 'bras bu yod par 'gyur la /
analyzed: shing gang dag chu dron po des bde bar skye bar 'gyur ba'i shing de dag ni lo ma yod pa dang / me tog yod pa dang / 'bras bu yod par 'gyur la /
translated: The trees that grow well with warm water have leaves, flowers and fruits.

original: shing gang dag chu dron po des bde bar skye bar mi 'gyur ba de dag ni lo ma med pa dang / me tog med pa dang / 'bras bu med par 'gyur te /
analyzed: shing gang dag chu dron po des bde bar skye bar mi 'gyur ba de dag ni lo ma med pa dang / me tog med pa dang / 'bras bu med par 'gyur te /
translated: The trees that do not grow well with warm water have no leaves, flowers and fruits.

original: rgyu des na dgun shing kha cig lo ma yod pa dang / me tog yod pa dang / 'bras bu yod par 'gyur la shing kha cig ni lo ma med pa dang / me tog med pa dang / 'bras bu med par 'gyur ro //
analyzed: rgyu des na dgun shing kha cig lo ma yod pa dang / me tog yod pa dang / 'bras bu yod par 'gyur la shing kha cig ni lo ma med pa dang / me tog med pa dang / 'bras bu med par 'gyur ro //
translated: For that reason, in winter some trees have leaves, flowers and fruits, while other trees have no leaves, flowers and fruits.

original: ci'i phyir ras bal zhes bya zhe na /ðŸ”½smras pa / bskal pa dang po'i mi rnams kyi dpag bsam shing las ras @172a * //
analyzed: ci'i phyir ras bal zhes bya zhe na / smras pa / bskal pa dang po'i mi rnams kyi dpag bsam shing las ras @172a * //
translated: Why is it called cotton?

original: byung ba gang yin pa de'i rgyu mthun ba las byung ba ni de yin te /
analyzed: byung ba gang yin pa de'i rgyu mthun ba las byung ba ni de yin te /
translated: It is said that it is the natural outcome of the wish-fulfilling trees of the humans of the first eon.

original: rgyu nges na ras bal zhes bya'o //
analyzed: rgyu nges na ras bal zhes bya'o //
translated: When the cause is definite, it is called cotton.

original: ci'i phyir dgun zhes bya zhe na /
analyzed: ci'i phyir dgun zhes bya zhe na /
translated: Why is it called winter?

original: smras pa / bskal pa dang po'i mi rnams kyi nags kyi ldum bur gyur pa gang yin pa de'i rgyu mthun pa las byung ba ni de yin te /
analyzed: smras pa / bskal pa dang po'i mi rnams kyi nags kyi ldum bur gyur pa gang yin pa de'i rgyu mthun pa las byung ba ni de yin te /
translated: It is said that it is the natural outflow of what was in the beginning of the eon a forest plant for the humans of that time.

original: rgyu des na dgun zhes bya'o //ðŸ”½ci'i phyir shing kha cig gye gur 'dug la /
analyzed: rgyu des na dgun zhes bya'o // ci'i phyir shing kha cig gye gur 'dug la /
translated: For that reason, it is called winter.

original: kha cig drang por 'dug ce na /
analyzed: kha cig drang por 'dug ce na /
translated: Why are some trees crooked and some straight?

original: smras pa / rlung gi dbang gis 'gyur te /ðŸ”½shing gang dag la rlung rnams mthun par 'gyur ba de dag ni drang por 'gyur ro //
analyzed: smras pa / rlung gi dbang gis 'gyur te / shing gang dag la rlung rnams mthun par 'gyur ba de dag ni drang por 'gyur ro //
translated: It is said that it is due to the power of the wind.ðŸ”½Those trees that the winds agree with become straight.

original: shing gang dag la rlung rnams mi mthun par gyur pa de dag ni gye gur 'dug ste /ðŸ”½rgyu des na shing kha cig gye gur 'dug la /
analyzed: shing gang dag la rlung rnams mi mthun par gyur pa de dag ni gye gur 'dug ste / rgyu des na shing kha cig gye gur 'dug la /
translated: Those trees that the winds do not agree with become crooked.

original: kha cig drang por 'dug go //
analyzed: kha cig drang por 'dug go //
translated: For that reason, some trees are crooked and some are straight.

original: ci'i phyir chu gcig gis brlan pa'i sa phyogs gcig tu shing kha dog sna tshogs dang / rtags sna tshogs dang / dbyibs sna tshogs su gyur te /
analyzed: ci'i phyir chu gcig gis brlan pa'i sa phyogs gcig tu shing kha dog sna tshogs dang / rtags sna tshogs dang / dbyibs sna tshogs su gyur te /
translated: Why is it that in a single place moistened by a single water, trees have various colors, various signs, and various shapes?

original: kha dog gcig par ma gyur /
analyzed: kha dog gcig par ma gyur /
translated: They do not have a single color.

original: rtags gcig par ma gyur /
analyzed: rtags gcig par ma gyur /
translated: They do not have a single sign.

original: dbyibs gcig par ma gyur zhe na /
analyzed: dbyibs gcig par ma gyur zhe na /
translated: They do not have a single shape.

original: smras pa / sa bon gyi dbang gis 'gyur te /
analyzed: smras pa / sa bon gyi dbang gis 'gyur te /
translated: It is said: It is due to the power of the seed.

original: sa bon ji ltar 'dug pa de bzhin du sa yang sa'i bcud len par byed /
analyzed: sa bon ji ltar 'dug pa de bzhin du sa yang sa'i bcud len par byed /
translated: Just as the seed is, so the earth takes up the essence of earth.

original: chu yang chu'i bcud len par byed /
analyzed: chu yang chu'i bcud len par byed /
translated: Water takes up the essence of water.

original: me yang me'i bcud len par byed /
analyzed: me yang me'i bcud len par byed /
translated: Fire takes up the essence of fire.

original: rlung yang rlung gi bcud len par byed de //
analyzed: rlung yang rlung gi bcud len par byed de //
translated: Wind takes up the essence of wind.

original: rgyu des na chu gcig gis brlan pa'i sa phyogs gcig tu shing kha dog sna tshogs dang / rtags sna tshogs dang / dbyibs sna tshogs su 'gyur te /
analyzed: rgyu des na chu gcig gis brlan pa'i sa phyogs gcig tu shing kha dog sna tshogs dang / rtags sna tshogs dang / dbyibs sna tshogs su 'gyur te /
translated: For that reason, in a single place moistened by a single water, trees have various colors, various signs, and various shapes.

original: kha dog gcig par ma gyur /
analyzed: kha dog gcig par ma gyur /
translated: They do not have a single color.

original: rtags gcig par ma gyur /
analyzed: rtags gcig par ma gyur /
translated: They do not have a single sign.

original: dbyibs gcig par ma gyur te //
analyzed: dbyibs gcig par ma gyur te //
translated: They do not have a single shape.

original: ci'i phyir shing thams cad la 'byung po yod par 'gyur te /
analyzed: ci'i phyir shing thams cad la 'byung po yod par 'gyur te /
translated: Why would all trees be inhabited by spirits?

original: 'byung po rnams kyis dben par ma gyur zhe na /
analyzed: 'byung po rnams kyis dben par ma gyur zhe na /
translated: Why would they not be devoid of spirits?ðŸ”½It is said:

original: smras pa / 'jig rten 'chags pa'i tshe /
analyzed: smras pa / 'jig rten 'chags pa'i tshe /
translated: When the world was forming,

original: shing snang bar byed pa'i 'byung po'i bdag po zhig tsandan gyi shing chen po zhig la gnas par gyur to //
analyzed: shing snang bar byed pa'i 'byung po'i bdag po zhig tsandan gyi shing chen po zhig la gnas par gyur to //
translated: a spirit lord of illuminating trees dwelt in a great sandalwood tree.

original: 'byung po lhag ma rnams ni de ma yin pa'i shing de dag la gnas par gyur te /
analyzed: 'byung po lhag ma rnams ni de ma yin pa'i shing de dag la gnas par gyur te /
translated: The remaining spirits dwelt in those other trees.ðŸ”½Since he was the first to dwell there, they passed it on to each other and others also came to dwell there.

original: de dag gi thog mar gnas su byas pas gcig nas gcig tu brgyud de gzhan dag kyang gnas par gyur pa dang / 'byung po dag gi shing rnams sme bag med pa dang / mchod rten gyi gnas lta bu dang / gtsang ba dang / yid du 'ong ba dang bsten pa'i 'os su byas te sme bag med par gyur pa dang /
analyzed: de dag gi thog mar gnas su byas pas gcig nas gcig tu brgyud de gzhan dag kyang gnas par gyur pa dang / 'byung po dag gi shing rnams sme bag med pa dang / mchod rten gyi gnas lta bu dang / gtsang ba dang / yid du 'ong ba dang bsten pa'i 'os su byas te sme bag med par gyur pa dang /
translated: The trees of the spirits became free of blemishes, like the site of a stupa, pure, pleasing, and worthy of being relied upon, and became free of blemishes.

original: mchod rten gyi @172b gnas lta bur gyur pa dang / gtsang bar gyur pa dang / yid du 'ong bar gyur pa dang / bstan ba'i 'os su gyur pa'i phyir 'byung po dag gis shing rnams gnas su byas te /
analyzed: mchod rten gyi @172b gnas lta bur gyur pa dang / gtsang bar gyur pa dang / yid du 'ong bar gyur pa dang / bstan ba'i 'os su gyur pa'i phyir 'byung po dag gis shing rnams gnas su byas te /
translated: Because trees are the abode of spirits, they are like the site of a stupa, they are pure, they are pleasing and they are worthy of being taught.

original: rgyu des na shing thams cad la 'byung po yod par gyur te /
analyzed: rgyu des na shing thams cad la 'byung po yod par gyur te /
translated: For this reason, all trees are the abode of spirits.

original: 'byung po rnams kyis dben par ma gyur te /
analyzed: 'byung po rnams kyis dben par ma gyur te /
translated: They are not devoid of spirits.

original: chos kyi rigs pa'i skabs bya ba dang / don dang rgyu dang 'bras bu la rmongs pa zlog par byed pa /
analyzed: chos kyi rigs pa'i skabs bya ba dang / don dang rgyu dang 'bras bu la rmongs pa zlog par byed pa /
translated: This concludes the chapter on the Abhidharma, the section on the causes and effects of phenomena, which is the antidote to confusion about the meaning and causes of results.

original: bzang 'gro thob par byed pa /
analyzed: bzang 'gro thob par byed pa /
translated: It is the means of attaining good rebirths.

original: sdug pa'i 'bras bur 'gyur bar byed pa /
analyzed: sdug pa'i 'bras bur 'gyur bar byed pa /
translated: It is the means of attaining pleasant results.

original: sangs rgyas dang / rang sangs rgyas dang / nyan thos kyis brtags pa'i chos mngon pa gdags pa'i bstan bcos rgyu gdags pa las tshigs bcu dgu pa rdzogs so /ðŸ”½// / rgyu gdags pa rdzogs te gnyis pa'o /
analyzed: sangs rgyas dang / rang sangs rgyas dang / nyan thos kyis brtags pa'i chos mngon pa gdags pa'i bstan bcos rgyu gdags pa las tshigs bcu dgu pa rdzogs so /ðŸ”½// / rgyu gdags pa rdzogs te gnyis pa'o /
translated: This concludes the nineteenth chapter of the Treatise on the Presentation of the Abhidharma, called The Presentation of Causes.

original: // / rgya gar gyi mkhan po dzi na mi tra dang pradzny'a bar ma dang / zhu chen gyi lo ts'a ba ban de ye shes sde la stsogs pas bsgyur cing zhus te gtan la phab pa//
analyzed: // / rgya gar gyi mkhan po dzi na mi tra dang pradzny'a bar ma dang / zhu chen gyi lo ts'a ba ban de ye shes sde la stsogs pas bsgyur cing zhus te gtan la phab pa//
translated: The Indian scholars Jinamitra and Prajfiabhava, and the chief editor, the Venerable Translator Yeshe De and others, translated and edited this text.
